title-group.article-title: Emission of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons from coal and sewage sludge co-combustion in a drop tube furnace

article-meta.aff: 1Hubei Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion and New Materials, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, Hubei, China
2State Key Laboratory of Coal Combustion, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, Hubei, China

author-notes.corresp: Hong Yao, State Key Laboratory of Coal Combustion, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, Hubei, China Email: hyao@hust.edu.cn

abstract.p: The emission characteristics of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) during coal and sewage sludge co-combustion were investigated in a laboratory-scale drop tube furnace. The experimental results demonstrated that coal and sewage sludge co-combustion was beneficial in reducing PAH emissions and PAH toxic equivalent (TEQ) concentrations. Meanwhile, the five-ring PAHs were the main contributor in reducing the concentration of PAHs and TEQ. Moreover, the two- and five-ring PAH concentrations decreased as the mass fraction of sewage sludge in the mixture increased from 0% to 100%. It was also found that PAHs from coal mono-combustion was dominated by the four- and five-ring PAHs. As for the sewage sludge mono-combustion, the three- and four-ring PAHs were the principal components.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sewage sludge is the largest by-product of wastewater treatment. In 2010, it was reported that about 18 million tonnes of sewage sludge was produced in China, and the annual increase rate of sewage sludge was about 8–10% (National Bureau Statistics of China, 2010), which was considered as one of the main environmental issues in China. At present, the main disposal methods include agricultural application, landfill and incineration. Before 2005, most sewage sludge was co-disposed with municipal solid waste (MSW) by landfill, which has been prohibited because of the high organic matter content in sewage sludge (Li et al., 2008). As for agricultural application, it may create a risk of accumulating heavy metals in soils, plants, and animal pastures (Gale, 2005; Smith et al., 2001). Consequently, it may induce serious human health problems (Bright and Healey, 2003; Jensen, 2003). Incineration has been considered as one of the most promising techniques for treating sewage sludge owing to its advantages in volume reduction and energy recovery. For example, over 50% of sewage sludge in Singapore, Switzerland, Luxemburg, Japan, Denmark, Sweden and Belgium is treated by incineration (Yao and Naruse, 2009). Yet, the lower heating value (LHV) of sewage sludge in China is only around 4186 kJ kg-1 (Yan et al., 1996), which barely meets the minimum requirement of incineration without auxiliary fuel. In order to solve the above problem, some scholars (Yan et al., 2006; Zhu et al., 2008) proposed that coal and sewage sludge co-combustion should be considered as one of the alternative technologies for treating sewage sludge. However, sewage sludge incineration will also produce some secondary pollutants, such as NOx, SO2, dioxins, heavy metals and other organic pollutants (Han et al., 2010; Vehlow et al., 2006).

Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a class of organic compounds composed of more than two benzene rings, which have been considered as potentially health hazardous substances owing to their immunotoxicity, genotoxicity, carcinogenicity and reproductive toxicity properties (Liu and Wang, 1995; Vehlow et al., 2006; Yue et al., 2003). The US Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) had designated 16 PAHs as priority pollutants (US-EPA, 1997). In 2004, the total global atmospheric emissions of 16 PAHs was estimated to be 520 Gg yr−1. PAH emissions from Asia, Africa, North America, Europe, South America and Oceania contributed 55%, 18.8%, 8.0%, 9.5%, 6.0% and 1.5% of the total global PAHs emissions, respectively (Zhang and Shu, 2009). The regulations or acts concerning PAHs have been enacted in many countries. For example, the Ontario Ministry of the Environment (MOE) updated the air quality standards for benzo[a]pyrene (BaP) concentration from 0.22 ng Nm−3 to 0.01 ng Nm−3. The European Union and China stipulated that the average daily BaP density could not surpass 0.22 to 0.01 ng Nm−3 and 10 ng Nm−3 in the atmosphere, respectively (GB3095-96, 1996; Mastral and Callén, 2000; Yin, 2007).

With more strict laws or regulations on the emission control of PAHs, such emissions have received widespread attention. Liu et al. (2009) investigated the emission characteristics of PAHs from the combustion of six different types of coals and found that the total emission concentration for 15 PAHs in gaseous and particulate phases ranged from 52.8 mg kg−1 to 1434.8 mg kg−1. The effects of operating parameters on PAHs emissions were also studied by Liu et al. (2001), who claimed that the emission of PAHs from a fluidized bed combustor were primarily dependent on combustion temperature and excess air ratio. Yan et al. (2002) and Li et al. (2002) also carried out experiments in fluidized- and fixed-bed combustors to determine the emission characteristics of PAHs and found that the amount of PAHs in flue gas during coal combustion was firstly increased and then decreased in the temperature range of 600°C to 1000°C. Similarly, the amount of PAHs in flue gas firstly increased and then decreased with an excess air ratio between 1.25 and 1.45 during sewage sludge and coal co-combustion (Zhu et al., 2008). The air flow rate in a fluidized bed combustor also has an important influence on organic emissions. Generally, the higher the flow rate, the higher the hydrocarbon emission. Meanwhile, the addition of limestone helps to control PAH emissions in the gas phase by adsorption (Mastral et al., 1999, 2001). In the case of sewage sludge and coal co-combustion (msludge/mcoal = 1:1), the concentration of 16 PAHs was markedly lower than that of sewage sludge mono-combustion (Deng et al., 2009). Chiang (1992) has pointed out that the addition of metal chloride promotes the rate of thermal decomposition of polystyrene plastics and subsequent reactions with benzene, which favors the formation and growth of PAHs.

However, few studies have reported the effects of coal and sewage sludge co-combustion on reducing PAHs and PAH toxic equivalent (TEQ) concentrations at a high temperature (the temperature in a pulverzied coal-fired power plant is >1300°C). In this study, the emission characteristics of PAHs and the PAH TEQ concentrations during coal and sewage sludge co-combustion were investigated in laboratory-scale drop tube furnace (DTF) experiments at a temperature of 1250°C.

sec.title: Raw materials
sec.p: A Chinese coal and municipal sewage sludge (MSS) were used as fuels in this experiment. The coal was from Henan province, China, whilst the MSS was obtained from a wastewater treatment plant in Wuhan City, China. Before the experiment, the coal and MSS were dried, milled and sieved to less than 74 μm respectively. Then, MSS was mixed with coal and the mass fractions of MSS to coal were 0/100, 10/90, 30/70 and 100/0. The properties of coal and MSS are summarized in Table 1. The ash and fixed carbon were the principal components of coal, whilst the volatile matter and fixed carbon in MSS were 45.39% and 6.83%, respectively. Moreover, elemental compositions of low temperature ashes (LTA) were analyzed by X-ray ﬂuorescence spectrometry (XRF), as shown in Table 1. Ca, Fe and Si levels in the MSS were relatively high; Al, P and S were lower than those in coals.

caption.p: The properties of coal and MSS (W%).

sec.title: Experimental apparatus
sec.p: The experiments were conducted in a laboratory-scale DTF that consisted of a feeding system, a high temperature furnace and a sampling system, as shown in Figure 1. The fuels entrained in a primary airflow were fed into the DTF by a Sankyo Piotech Micro Feeder (Model MFEV-10; Sankyo Piotech Co., Osaka, Japan); the feeding rate was 0.3 g min−1. The furnace has a length of 2 m and an inner diameter of 56 mm. It was electrically heated by three sections and the temperature of the furnace was automatically controlled by thermocouples. The experimental temperature was 1250°C. The primary airflow was mixed with the feeding fuels prior to entering the furnace; the primary airflow feed rate was 1 l min−1. In order to provide a laminar combustion environment, secondary airflow was given via the injector; the secondary airflow feed rate was 4 l min−1. The residence time of fuels in the furnace was about 2 s in all runs. The sampling system consisted of a stainless sampling probe, a cooling tube and an absorption bottle. The stainless sampling probe was water-cooled to prevent further reactions. After cooling the sampling probe, the flue gas was introduced in a glass ﬁber ﬁlter to capture the particle-phase PAHs; other PAHs were captured by an adsorption tube packed with 2.5 g XAD-2 resin and an absorption bottle filled with dichloromethane. The sampling flow rate of flue gas was 5 l min−1 and the sampling time was at 15-min intervals. After sampling, the glass ﬁber ﬁlter, XAD-2 resin and the absorption solution of dichloromethane were collected in a brown ground ﬂask and stored in a refrigerator. Experiments of each run were repeated three times and the average data were used. In addition, the concentrations of CO, CO2, SO2, NOX and O2 in the flue gas were recorded by a gas analyzer (PG-250, Horiba Corp, Kyoto, Japan). The experimental conditions and the flue gas composition are presented in Table 2.

caption.p: A schematic diagram of the drop tube furnace.
Experimental conditions and compositions of the flue gas.

sec.title: Analysis procedure
sec.p: All samples containing PAHs were first extracted for 16 h by Soxhlet extraction with dichloromethane as a solvent and condensed to 1 ml by a Kuderna-Danish (K-D) concentrator. Then, the concentrated solution was purified through a purifying tube packed with activated silica gel. The purified solution was condensed to 1 ml using a K-D concentrator and pure nitrogen (Tsai et al., 2002; You, 2008; Zhou et al., 2009). Finally, the extracted samples were transferred into brown vials and stored at 4°C for high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis (Zhou et al., 2009).

The extracted samples were analyzed by a HPLC system coupled to an ultraviolet (UV) detector. The emission wavelengths of the UV detector were 224 nm, 254 nm and 287 nm respectively. The HPLC column was a C18 column (length 250 mm, 4.6 mm i.d.). The mobile phase was methyl alcohol and water in the gradient mode at a flow rate of 0.8 ml min−1 with the column oven set at 30°C. The gradient elution program was as follows: an initial mobile phase at 60/40 (v/v) methyl alcohol and water at the beginning 2.5 min hold; 22.5 min linear gradient to 80% of methyl alcohol and maintained the proportion of methyl alcohol (80%) from 25 min to 40 min; 10 min linear gradient to 100% methyl alcohol; 5 min linear gradient to 60% methyl alcohol and 5 min hold. The injection volume was 20μl. Before the experiment, the HPLC was calibrated with a diluted standard solution of 16 PAH compounds recommended by the US EPA. The PAHs were analyzed and standardized by means of their retention times and peak areas of the calibration standards.

sec.title: Calculations for PAH TEQ concentrations
sec.p: The toxic equivalent factor (TEF) is generally used to assess the harmfulness of PAHs from the view of health-risk assessment (Tsai et al., 2002). The toxicity of PAHs is expressed as TEF in relation to the most toxic PAHs (BaP). Table 3 shows the TEF of 16 PAHs specified by the US EPA. Here, the concentration of 16 PAHs is also converted to the toxic equivalent (TEQ) concentration based on TEF. PAH TEQ concentrations are calculated as follows:

caption.p: Toxic equivalent factor (TEF) of 16 polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

fn.p: Nap, naphthalene; BaA, benz[a]anthracene; AcPy, acenaphthylene; Chr, chrysene; AcP, acenaphthene; BbF, benzo(b)fluorathene; Flu, fluorene; BkF, benzo[k]fluoranthene; PhA, phenanthrene; BaP, benzo[a]pyrene; AnT, anthracene; DbA, dibenzo(a,h)anthrance; FluA, fluoranthene; BghiP, benzo(ghi)perylene; Pyr, pyrene; InP, indeno[1,2,3-cd]pyrene.

sec.p: TEQi is the TEQ concentration of the ith PAH (μg TEQ Nm−3), CPAHi is the concentration of the ith PAH (μg TEQ Nm−3) and TEFPAHi is the TEF of the ith PAH. Hence, the total TEQ concentration of 16 PAHs specified by the US EPA is calculated as:
TEQ is the total TEQ concentration of the 16 specified PAHs (μg TEQ Nm−3).

sec.title: PAH and TEQ concentrations
sec.p: The distribution of PAHs during coal and MSS co-combustion at 1250°C is presented in Figure 2 and Figure 3. Figure 2 demonstrates that the mass fractions of MSS have an important impact on individual PAH emission and that the influence of the MSS mass fraction on individual PAH emission is irregular. The concentrations of anthracene (AnT), fluoranthene (FluA) and pyrene (Pyr) are 283 μg Nm−3, 351 μg Nm−3 and 225 μg Nm−3, respectively, making them the dominant PAHs during MSS mono-combustion. Acenaphthylene (AcPy), acenaphthene (AcP), chrysene (Chr) and benzo[k]fluoranthene (BkF) are insignificant in flue gas. As for coal mono-combustion, naphthalene (Nap), FluA, Pyr, BkF and BaP are the primary components of PAHs. In the case of 10/90 (MSS/coal) co-combustion, Nap, phenanthrene (PhA), AnT and FluA are the main components of the PAHs. The concentrations of Nap, PhA, AnT and FluA are 338 μg Nm−3, 268 μg Nm−3, 264 μg Nm−3 and 249 μg Nm−3 respectively. As the mass fraction of sewage sludge increased to 30%, Nap, FluA and Pyr were found at concentrations of 193 μg Nm−3, 218 μg Nm−3 and 319 μg Nm−3, respectively, which are the principal components in PAHs during 30/70 (MSS/coal) co-combustion. This phenomenon could be explained by the fact that coal is characterized by complex high-molecular compounds which are connected through fatty groups or bridge bonds, and the pyolysis decomposition is the primary process for PAH formation. Whilst sewage sludge contains high volatile matter and low fixed carbon, PAHs are formed mainly from the vaporization of volatile matters and synthesis processes. Figure 3 compares the distribution of PAH rings under different MSS/coal ratios. It can be seen that four- and five-ring PAHs are the primary PAHs during coal mono-combustion, whilst three- and four-ring PAHs are abundant during MSS mono-combustion. In the case of coal and MSS co-combustion, three-, four- and five-ring PAHs are the most dominant ones. Three-ring PAH concentrations produced from coal, 10/90 (MSS/coal), 30/70 (MSS/coal) and MSS combustion are 266 μg Nm−3, 672 μg Nm−3, 336 μg Nm−3 and 396 μg Nm−3 respectively. The concentration of four-ring PAHs decreases from 730 μg Nm−3 to 329 μg Nm−3 as the mass fraction of MSS decreases from 100% to 10%, and then increases to 602 μg Nm−3 without MSS. The variation of six-ring PAH concentrations is similar to that of the four-ring PAHs. In addition, the contents of two- and five-ring PAHs increases with the decrease of the mass fraction of sewage sludge from 100% to 0%. Figure 3 also presents the emissions of the total PAHs under different sewage sludge/coal ratios. PAH emissions during coal, 10/90 (MSS/coal), 30/70 (MSS/coal) and MSS combustion are 2510 ± 57 μg Nm−3, 1796 ± 47 μg Nm−3, 1688 ± 6 μg Nm−3 and 1939 ± 33 μg Nm−3 respectively.

caption.p: The distribution of individual polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). MSS, municipal sewage sludge; Nap, naphthalene; AcPy, acenaphythlene; AcP, acenapthene; Flu, fluorene; PhA, phenanthrene; AnT, anthracene; FluA, fluoranthene; Pyr, pyrene; BaA, benz[a]anthracene; Chr, chrysene; BbF, benzo(b)fluorathene; BkF, benzo[k]fluoranthene; BaP, benzo[a]pyrene; DbA, dibenzo(a,h)anthrance; InP, indeno[1,2,3-cd]pyrene ; BghiP, benzo(ghi)perylene.
The distribution and concentration of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). MSS, municipal sewage sludge.

sec.p: PAH TEQ concentrations under different MSS/coal combustion are provided in Table 4. It can be seen that BaP, DbA and BkF are the three most dominant PAH TEQ concentrations, followed by Benz[a]anthracene[BaA], Benzo(b)ﬂuoranthene[BbF], and Benzo(ghi)perylene (BghiP). Meanwhile, the five-ring PAH TEQ concentrations during coal, 10/90 (MSS/coal), 30/70 (MSS/coal) and MSS combustion are 821 ± 35 μg TEQ Nm−3, 317 ± 24 μg TEQ Nm−3, 258 ± 20 μg TEQ Nm−3 and 306 ± 10 μg TEQ Nm−3, respectively, which accounts for 92.12%, 92.18%, 96.02% and 98.13% of the total PAH TEQ concentration. Thus, five-ring PAHs are the main contributors to the TEQ concentration.

caption.p: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) toxic equivalent (TEQ) concentrations under different municipal sewage sludge (MSS)/coal combustion.

fn.p: Nap, naphthalene; AcPy, acenaphythlene; AcP, acenapthene; Flu, fluorene; PhA, phenanthrene; AnT, anthracene; FluA, fluoranthene; Pyr, pyrene; BaA, benz[a]anthracene; Chr, chrysene; BbF, dibenzo(a,h)anthrance; BkF, benzo[k]fluoranthene; BaP, benzo[a]pyrene; DbA, dibenzo(a,h)anthrance; InP, indeno[1,2,3-cd]pyrene; BghiP, benzo(ghi)perylene.

sec.title: Reduction of PAHs and PAH TEQ concentrations
sec.p: In order to discuss the effect of MSS addition to PAH emission, PAHs and PAH TEQ concentrations during coal and MSS co-combustion were compared with their calculated results.
The calculated value of PAHs or PAH TEQ concentrationss (CVP) are calculated by following equations:

where, CVP is the calculated concentration of PAHs or PAH TEQs during coal and MSS co-combustion; PAHsMSS is PAH concentrations in flue gas during MSS mono-combustion; PAHscoal is PAH concentrations in flue gas during coal mono-combustion; WMSS is mass fraction of MSS in fuel; Wcoal is the mass fraction of coal in fuel.

The comparisons of PAH emissions from coal and MSS co-combustion with their calculated values are presented in Figures 4 and 5. Compared with their calculated values, the concentrations of AcP, FluA, Pyr, BaA, BbF, BkF, BaP, DbA, Indeno[1,2,3-cd]pyrene (InP) and BghiP in the experimental results are significantly lower, as shown in Figure 4. Figure 5 indicates that the five-ring PAHs are the main contribution in reducing the PAHs. In the case of 10/90 (MSS/Coal) co-combustion, the reduction in PAHs is 600 μg Nm−3 (54.7%) for the five-ring PAHs and 606 μg Nm−3 (25.2%) for the total PAH concentration. In contrast, compared with their calculated values, the three-ring PAHs increased. When the mass fraction of MSS is increased to 30%, the five-ring PAHs and the total PAH concentrations are decreased by 491 μg Nm−3 (55.0%) and 598 μg Nm−3 (26.2%) respectively. The above results indicate that coal and MSS co-combustion are beneficial in reducing PAH emission, especially with regard to five-ring PAHs. The reason may be that PAHs are products of incomplete combustion and the addition of MSS can improve the combustion efficiency, which can reduce PAH emission.

caption.p: Comparison of individual polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) emissions with their calculated values. MSS, municipal sewage sludge; Exp., expected; Cal., calculated; Nap, naphthalene; AcPy, acenaphythlene; AcP, acenapthene; Flu, fluorene; PhA, phenanthrene; AnT, anthracene; FluA, fluoranthene; Pyr, pyrene; BaA, benz[a]anthracene; Chr, chrysene; BbF, benzo(b)ﬂuoranthene; BkF, benzo[k]fluoranthene; BaP, benzo[a]pyrene; DbA, dibenzo(a,h)anthrance; InP, indeno[1,2,3-cd]pyrene; BghiP, benzo(ghi)perylene.
Comparison of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) emissions with their calculated values. MSS, municipal sewage sludge; Exp., expected; Cal., calculated.

sec.p: PAH TEQ concentrations during coal and MSS co-combustion are also compared with their calculated results and listed in Table 5. Compared with the calculated values, PAH TEQ concentrations during 10/90 (MSS/Coal) or 30/70 (MSS/Coal) co-combustion are significantly reduced. Meanwhile, BaP and DbA are the main contributions in reducing the total PAH TEQ concentrations. PAH TEQ concentrations from 10/90 (MSS/Coal) co-combustion are decreased by 410 μg TEQ Nm−3 (56.5%) for the five-ring PAHs and 414 μg TEQ Nm−3 (55.7%) for total PAHs. In the case of 30/70 (MSS/Coal) co-combustion, the reduction amounts of the five-ring PAHs and total PAH TEQ concentrations are 390 μg TEQ Nm−3 (59.6%) and 385 μg TEQ Nm−3 (58.1%) respectively.

caption.p: Comparison of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) toxic equivalent (TEQ) concentrations with their calculated values.

fn.p: Nap, naphthalene; AcPy, acenaphythlene; AcP, acenapthene; Flu, fluorene; PhA, phenanthrene; AnT, anthracene; FluA, fluoranthene; Pyr, pyrene; BaA, benz[a]anthracene; Chr, chrysene; BbF, benzo(b)ﬂuoranthene; BkF, benzo[k]fluoranthene; BaP, benzo[a]pyrene; DbA, dibenzo(a,h)anthrance; InP, indeno[1,2,3-cd]pyrene; BghiP, benzo(ghi)perylene; MSS, municipal sewage sludge; Exp., expected; Cal., calculated.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: PAH emissions during coal and MSS co-combustion were experimentally studied in a laboratory-scale DTF at 1250ºC. It was found that the addition of MSS during coal combustion can reduce the PAH concentration and PAH TEQ concentrations. PAH emissions under 10/90 (MSS/Coal) or 30/70 (MSS/Coal) co-combustion were reduced by 606 μg Nm−3 and 598 μg Nm−3 respectively. Meanwhile, five-rings PAHs are the main contribution to reducing PAHs and the TEQ concentrations during coal and MSS co-combustion. Moreover, PAH emission during coal mono-combustion is dominated by four- and five-ring PAHs. As for MSS mono-combustion, three- and four-ring PAHs are the principal components. The two- and five-ring PAH concentrations are decreased as the mass fraction of MSS increases from 0% to 100%.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This work was partly supported by Key Project of Chinese National Programs for Fundamental Research and Development (973 program, 2011CB201505), National Natural Science Foundation of China (51161140330, 50806053), Youth Scientist Dawn Foundation of Wuhan Government (201050231047), Foundation of State Key Laboratory of Coal Combustion (FSKLCC1113).
